arm_group.description: Any patient eligible for an Ultrasound greater than or equal to 18 weeks gestation without a fetal or uterine anomaly.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to detect if adding resistance to maternal blood flow from the
      arm will help increase the blood flow through the uterine arteries to the placenta and the
      baby.

condition: Greater Than or Equal to 18 Weeks Gestation

detailed_description.textblock:
In the setting of uteroplacental insufficiency, there is little that can be done to increase
      blood flow through the uterus and placenta.  Historically, women with growth restricted
      fetuses or oligohydramnios have been placed on bed rest.  Unfortunately, this treatment
      modality has met with only limited success.  Cardiologists have long recognized the simple
      act of making a fist or otherwise occluding blood flow through a limb dramatically increases
      a person's peripheral vascular resistance.  If maternal peripheral resistance can be
      increased, perhaps the increased differential between the maternal peripheral vascular
      resistance and that of the uteroplacental unit will increase flow through the uterus and
      placenta.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Pregnant women greater than or equal to 18 years old

          -  Able to speak and read English

          -  Have a singleton pregnancy greater than or equal to 18 weeks gestation

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Multiple gestation

          -  Less than 18 weeks gestation

          -  Uterine anomalies

          -  Fetal anomalies

          -  Preeclampsia

          -  Hypertension

          -  Inability to have BP cuff on left arm

study_pop.textblock:
Pregnant women greater than or equal to 18 weeks gestation and 18 years old eligible for
        an ultrasound without fetal or uterine anomalies

intervention.intervention_name: Any patient eligible for an Ultrasound greater than or equal to 18 weeks gestation without a fetal or uterine anomaly.

clinical_study.official_title: A Simple Technique to Modify Maternal Uterine Artery Perfusion.

primary_outcome.description: The purpose of this study is to detect if adding resistance to maternal blood flow from the arm will help increase the blood flow through the uterine arteries to the placenta and the baby.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective
